data.text: Is a Touring-Specific Bicycle Necessary for a Multi-Week Cross-Country Ride?
Do I necessarily have to have a touring bike to travel over multiple weeks on a cross country ride.
Not really, youcan use whatever you like. However a touring bike, might provide to be more reliable, better suited....
data.author: Ian Beacham

data.text: Some people do it on a unicycle... it's up to you. Touring specific bikes simply have geometry and mounts that male life easier on your trip.
data.author: Mark Stratmann

data.text: Yup! And having the right gears to handle the hills you might encounter. If been outright beaten down by some climbs for which I had neither the legs nor the low gears to handle.
data.author: David Law

data.text: Whatever you have will work. Make sure you have the gearing necessary for whatever topography you are planning to cover, and the bike has the ability to carry your gear, you have the bike properly fit to you, and have a good set of wheels.
data.author: Ryan Jeambey

data.text: This!
data.author: Tom Etheridge

data.text: People have posted on FB having toured across India on a folding shopping bike!
data.author: James Hubbard

data.text: I have toured on a Brompton since 2011 but multi day not multi week. On my own or with 2 friends also with Bromptons.
data.author: Christine Roche

data.text: I'm not brave enough to do it on 16 inch wheels, but plenty do üòÄ
data.author: James Hubbard
Dan Hurley

data.text: Not necessarily a touring bike, but definitely an appropriate bike. I don't agree with the "any bike is appropriate" line - for a multiple-week tour, a poorly-suited bike could make it an unpleasant experience. As an extreme example, a time trial bike with stiff frame and wheels would be very uncomfortable and require a lot of bodging to fix bags to.
data.author: David Rowe

data.text: i agree
data.author: Fashilah Ahmad

data.text: there was a time when they were the same bike, 531, 73deg parallel frame, with mudguards and saddle bag tourist, without add racing wheels, time trialist
data.author: Clive Robin Britten

data.text: Yes, I'd often put a decent saddle bag on my Colnago Super Mexico for an all-day century+ ride, but I wouldn't want to use it for a multiple-week bikepacking trip. Nowhere to easily put bags (and frame not suitable), and widest tyre it would fit was 25mm. As much as I loved that bike, it was not a multiple-week touring bike.
data.author: David Rowe

data.text: I suppose. I met a kid on a carbon racing bike pulling a lightly weighted BOB on tour. Any bike certainly has to fit well. But I think it IS possible to tour on anything. Is it advisable? It's subjective. The industry would have us all believe that we NEED to have this or that bike to be successful. Personally, I try to stick to gravel, dirt and single track anymore. I tour on two bikes. I switch them depending on my route. One is steel 29x2 and something. Or for the desert, I like my aluminum fat cargo bike. 27.5x 4.
data.author: Robin Brodsky

data.text: Without knowing anything about the OP, anecdotes about individuals riding what for the majority of people would be completely inappropriate bikes doesn't help. It would take an exceptional person who would enjoy using a time trial bike for an extended bikepacking trip.
data.author: David Rowe

data.text: Nope! I used a commuter bike for my 1400km tour last year
data.author: Christie Ogden

data.text: I used a gravel bike. The biggest issue is how much weight your bike and rims can manage.
data.author: Bill Debs

data.text: I've been touring 8 months a year since the early 1980s. You can travel on just about any bike you're willing to ride. I ride a 26x4 twenty-seven speed FAT bike.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: I tour on a fat bike also, but only 16 gears. It‚Äôs a darn fine ride for comfort, and ability to carry bags, but not necessarily speed. For me, it‚Äôs about the journey.
data.author: Diane Farley

data.text: I toured on a 7 speed FAT bike once and it was okay but climbing hills was harder. It was this Trek Electra cruiser bike.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: I travel a 300+ mile loop twice a year on a cheap steel frame shwin that cost less than $200 new. Ride what you want to or can afford I buy cheap because I live in a ghetto town where crackheads steal grass blades.
data.author: Sam Smith

data.text: Fit and comfort are the most important factors to avoid pain, sores and blisters.
data.author: Ed Melby

data.text: I have been a Warmshowers host for seven years and basically you can tour on any bike that is reliable. A young Belgian arrived on a step through city bike. At the other extreme was a W√®lshman who was bikepacking on a full carbon Trek and riding 150 to 200kms a day
data.author: Dell Edwards

data.text: No. I rode from Northern Colorado to Waco, Texas on this one, about 6 years ago. I attached a rear rack, with a spare front wheel mounted horizontally on it to carry gear. I also kept my tools in a handlebar bag to help balance the weight. Have fun!
data.author: Joshua Van Schoik

data.text:
I had a friend cross the US from Wa to Md on an old single speed Schwinn upright. I always say ‚Äú ride what you got‚Äù. She didn‚Äôt tote loads of bags, just one small one. She stayed in ‚Äúwarm showers.org‚Äù offerings.
showers.org
showers.org
data.author: Bob Roberts

data.text: Nope. You can ride whatever you like. The best bike is the one you already have...
data.author: Robin Brodsky

data.text: A bike with a short wheelbase and a steep head tube is going to be twitchy and require constant steering input and, therefore, be mentally and physically exhausting.
data.author: Steve Williams

data.text: I believe it can be any bike as long as you have motivation and enthusiasm to ride it. Inappropriate bike will cost you more strength both mentally and physically but you can still make it
data.author: Damian Terpitz

data.text: Did my first multiple day biking trip on a 25 year old city bike. It had like 5 gears and cheap aluminium frame and wheels. I carried 25 kg of stuff on it, didn't even have proper bags. It was a bit wobbly and the breaks weren't too great, but it worked. Had the time of my life and have since then invested in a better bike (although the 'new' one is 17 years old as well ü§£ at least it's a steel frame) Just go for it, make it work for you with whatever you have. You'll love it! Happy travels ü§ó
data.author: Jessica Kittle

data.text: Comfortable, able to carry racks panniers. Good strong wheelset Pretty much all u need when looking for a bike to go the distance.
data.author: Topher Nando

data.text: Nope. I have a gravel bike.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: CC
data.author: Jeff Neumann

data.text: No you do not. But how comfortable will you be, how easy will it be to carry gear and pedal up long grades, how much maintenance will you need to do to get from point A to B. People will tell you can can tour on anything but tour bikes have unique geometry, tripple chainrings and many mounting points for a reason
data.author: Jesse Justice

data.text: Darn , they steal the grass blades.. !?
data.author: Frank Geraci

data.text: Need a bit more info. ‚ÄúTouring Bike‚Äù is generally known as a road bike with an expanded gear range and slightly larger tires with F & R racks for saddle bags. My question is how much do you weigh, and what do you want to carry?
data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text: I tour on a 27 speed FAT bike. I only carry the basics my tent, sleeping bag and pad, stove and cook gear. Spare clothes and food and water of course. I only carry 15 lbs of gear including the weight of my panniers and handle bar bag. No need to carry too much!
data.author: Gary Palmer
Gary Palmer

data.text: , Nice set up. Carry only 15lbs in all those bags? You say ‚Äúno need to carry too much‚Äù,.. well that‚Äôs relative isn‚Äôt it? You‚Äôre not going out to the middle of Borneo, hundreds of miles away from civilization with just 15lbs. It that tubeless? Conventional J bend spokes?
data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text: not tubeless, have Slime tubes. Standard spokes. I've been touring 40 years since 1982. And yes just 15 lbs, not counting food and water.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: the furthest I've ever toured between supplies is 125 miles from Joshua Tree CA to Parker AZ.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: I won't be carrying anything we will have SAG hauling all of our stuff.
data.author: Burke Flynt

data.text: I‚Äôm guessing a SAG is a support vehicle?
data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text: yes it is
data.author: Burke Flynt

data.text: Not at all if there's SAG support to carry the load. A century or fondo style road bike is intended to be more comfortable than a race bike for long days of riding and is my choice for most riding. That is certainly a reasonable choice if you have SAG support.
data.author: Gordo S. Groundchuck

data.text: Depends on the roads you'll be riding
data.author: Scout Ess

data.text: Also, don‚Äôt take your carbon frame bike!
data.author: Radfield Justice

data.text: if I'm not putting panniers and such on my bike why could I not use a carbon fiber bike?
data.author: Burke Flynt

data.text: you can certainly.
data.author: Radfield Justice
Michael Buckstone

Ryan Van Duzer road a mountain bike from Honduras to Boulder, Colorado and then rode a 3 speed across the country. https://youtu.be/6Puf15qw5Y0
The Epic Stories Behind All of My Bikes

data.author: Deb Thomas

data.text: Nope,
data.author: David Atwell

data.text: All bikes are touring bikes if you take em on tour.
data.author: John Bobstone

data.text: sounds good
data.author: Burke Flynt

data.text: I feel like a lot of people spend too much time worrying about equipment. Get in the saddle and send it down the road. Use what ya got and have fun
data.author: John Bobstone
